The module includes general content about business analysis such as: concepts of business analysis, business analysts, core conceptual models in business analysis, tools, and analytical skills business, requirements and requirement lifecycle; business analysis planning; Elicit and collaborate with stakeholders to define business requirements, manage requirements lifecycle, analyze requirements and define solutions; solution evaluation.

The module also helps students practice thinking skills and the ability to self-study knowledge related to business analysis. Students have the ability to work independently and in groups. Students can apply the knowledge they have learned to solve real-life professional problems.
[1]. Business Analysis Body of Knowledge, Version 3, International Institute of Business Analysis
[2]. Paul & Kate & Kupe (2013), Business analysis for dummies, John Wiley & Son, Inc
[3]. Hans Jonasson (2017), CBAP certification and BABOK study guide, Taylor & Francis Group.
[4]. James Cadle & Debra Paul & Paul Turner (2010), Business Analysis Techniques: 72 essential tools for success, British Computer Society.

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

* Title: Business Analysis Code: CNTT1137
* Credits: 3 (45)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 18 hrs.
+ Exercises on class: 15 hrs.
+ Presentation and Discussion: 12 hrs.
+ Self-study: 60 hrs.
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128; TIKT1130
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)
+ Department: Department of Information Technology
+ Lecturers:
* Kind of the course:
* Course language: In English
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 13.10, Building A1, National Economics University
The module includes general content about business analysis such as: concepts of business analysis, business analysts, core conceptual models in business analysis, tools, and analytical skills business, requirements and requirement lifecycle; business analysis planning; Elicit and collaborate with stakeholders to define business requirements, manage requirements lifecycle, analyze requirements and define solutions; solution evaluation.
The module also helps students practice thinking skills and the ability to self-study knowledge related to business analysis. Students have the ability to work independently and in groups. Students can apply the knowledge they have learned to solve real-life professional problems.
* Textbooks/Lecture Notes:
[1]. Business Analysis Body of Knowledge, Version 3, International Institute of Business Analysis
[2]. Paul & Kate & Kupe (2013), Business analysis for dummies, John Wiley & Son, Inc
* Additional references:
[3]. Hans Jonasson (2017), CBAP certification and BABOK study guide, Taylor & Francis Group.
[4]. James Cadle & Debra Paul & Paul Turner (2010), Business Analysis Techniques: 72 essential tools for success, British Computer Society.
